content.heading: Axolotl Water Care Guide
content.text: Regular water maintenance is THE foundation of axolotl health. Even perfect filtration cannot eliminate nitrates—only water changes remove these toxins. This guide covers weekly water change protocols, water conditioner safety (critical: aloe vera kills axolotls), proper acclimation techniques, and emergency responses to water quality crises.
NEVER use water conditioners containing aloe vera or "stress coat" formulas—aloe is toxic to axolotls and causes severe illness or death. Use ONLY Seachem Prime or Fritz Complete water conditioners.
Water changes are NON-NEGOTIABLE for axolotl health. No amount of filtration eliminates the need for regular water changes.

content.text: Never change more than 50% of water at once unless emergency. Large water changes disrupt beneficial bacteria colonies and shock axolotls with rapid parameter shifts.
Preparation (Before Starting)

items: Test Water: Check ammonia, nitrites, nitrates, pH, temperature—record baseline
Prepare New Water: Fill buckets with tap water, add water conditioner (Seachem Prime), let sit 5-10 minutes
Temperature Match: New water should be 60-68°F, within 2°F of tank temperature
Gather Equipment: Siphon/gravel vacuum, buckets (axolotl-dedicated, never use cleaning chemicals), thermometer, conditioner

content.text: Step 1: Remove Old Water

items: Insert siphon hose into tank, start siphon flow (mouth-start or pump-start)
Vacuum substrate surface—siphon waste, uneaten food, debris
For bare-bottom: hover siphon 1 inch above glass, suction waste without disturbing axolotl
For sand: hover 1-2 inches above sand—waste sits on top, avoid sucking sand
For slate tile: vacuum around and between tiles
Remove 20-30% water volume (40 gallon tank = 8-12 gallons removed)
Avoid sucking up axolotl—gently guide away if it approaches siphon

content.text: Step 2: Clean Tank Components (Monthly)

items: Filter Intake: Wipe sponge/strainer with tank water—removes debris
Decorations: Remove visible algae with soft brush or scraper (rinse in tank water, NOT tap)
Glass: Scrape algae from viewing panels with aquarium scraper
Never Use Soap: Soap residue is lethal—clean only with hot water or tank water

content.text: Step 3: Add New Water

items: Double-check new water temperature (60-68°F, within 2°F of tank)
Slowly pour new water into tank—pour onto decoration or hand to diffuse flow (avoids disturbing axolotl)
Fill to original water level
Turn filter/heater/chiller back on if turned off during change
Wait 30 minutes, test parameters—ammonia and nitrites should still be 0 ppm

content.text: NEVER add untreated tap water directly to tank with axolotl inside. Always condition water BEFORE adding, or temporarily remove axolotl during change. Chlorine burns gills within seconds.
Water conditioners remove chlorine and chloramine from tap water. However, many common conditioners contain ingredients TOXIC to axolotls.

items: Seachem Prime (BEST CHOICE): Removes chlorine/chloramine, detoxifies ammonia/nitrites for 24-48 hours, no harmful additives. Highly concentrated—5 ml treats 50 gallons.
Fritz Complete: Removes chlorine/chloramine, adds beneficial minerals, no aloe vera or plant extracts. Good alternative to Prime.
API Tap Water Conditioner (BASIC): Removes chlorine/chloramine only—no extra features. Safe but less effective than Prime during emergencies.
API Stress Coat: Contains aloe vera—TOXIC to axolotls, causes severe skin/gill irritation, often fatal
Tetra AquaSafe Plus: Contains plant extracts—potentially harmful to axolotls
Any "Stress Coat" or "Slime Coat" Formulas: Contain aloe vera or plant extracts—avoid completely
ReptiSafe: Despite name, some formulations contain aloe—verify ingredients or use Prime instead

content.text: If you accidentally used aloe-containing conditioner, IMMEDIATELY perform 75% water change with Seachem Prime-treated water. Monitor axolotl for 48 hours for signs of distress (curled gills, mucus overproduction, lethargy).
Not all water sources are safe or practical for axolotl tanks.

content.text: Tap Water Testing

items: Test tap water BEFORE first use: pH, GH, KH, chlorine/chloramine presence
Most city tap water is 7.0-8.0 pH—acceptable for axolotls
If pH below 6.5 or above 8.5, consider pH buffering or alternative water source
All city tap water contains chlorine or chloramine—ALWAYS condition
Annual water quality reports available from city—check for heavy metal concerns

content.text: Proper acclimation when introducing axolotl to new tank or after transport prevents osmotic shock and stress.
When to Use: New axolotl arrival, moving between tanks with similar parameters

items: Step 1: Float sealed bag/container in tank for 15-20 minutes—equalizes temperature
Step 2: Open bag, add 1/4 cup tank water to bag—wait 10 minutes
Step 3: Add another 1/4 cup tank water—wait 10 minutes
Step 4: Repeat step 3 two more times (total 4 additions over 45 minutes)
Step 5: Gently net axolotl (or use hands with wet gloves), transfer to tank
Step 6: Discard bag water—DO NOT add shipping water to tank (contains waste, potential pathogens)
Step 7: Turn off lights, let axolotl settle for 24 hours before feeding

content.text: When to Use: pH difference exceeding 0.5 units, temperature difference exceeding 5°F, moving from store tank to home tank

items: Step 1: Place axolotl in large bucket/container with shipping water
Step 2: Set up airline tubing from tank to bucket (siphon drip)
Step 3: Tie knot in airline tubing to slow drip to 2-3 drops per second
Step 4: Let tank water drip into bucket for 1-2 hours until bucket volume doubles
Step 5: Remove 50% water from bucket, continue dripping another 30 minutes
Step 6: Net axolotl, transfer to tank
Step 7: Discard acclimation water, turn off lights, let settle 24 hours

content.text: NEVER rush acclimation. Rapid parameter changes cause osmotic shock, gill damage, and increased disease susceptibility. Allow minimum 45 minutes for float method, 90 minutes for drip method.
Minimize handling—axolotls have delicate skin and protective slime coat easily damaged.
When Handling Is Necessary

items: Acclimation/tank transfer
Medical treatment/examination
Emergency evacuation (power outage, tank leak)
Separating aggressive tank mates

content.text: Safe Handling Method

items: Wet Hands Thoroughly: Dry hands damage slime coat—soak hands in tank water first
Use Soft Net: Fine mesh net preferred over coarse nets (reduces fin damage)
Scoop from Below: Gently slide cupped hands under axolotl, support entire body
Minimize Air Exposure: Transfer quickly (under 30 seconds in air)
Never Grab Gills/Tail: These structures are extremely delicate and easily damaged
No Squeezing: Gentle support only—no pressure on body

content.text: When ammonia, nitrites detected, or temperature exceeds 74°F, immediate large water change required.

items: Step 1 (Immediate): Remove 50% water, replace with conditioned, temperature-matched water
Step 2 (15 min later): Dose Seachem Prime at 5× normal dose—temporarily detoxifies ammonia/nitrites for 24-48 hours
Step 3 (1 hour later): Test parameters—if ammonia/nitrites still detectable, repeat 25% water change
Step 4 (Ongoing): Daily 25-50% water changes until parameters stabilize at 0 ppm for 3 consecutive days
Step 5: Stop feeding until parameters stable—food produces ammonia
Step 6: Add beneficial bacteria supplement (Seachem Stability) daily
Step 7: Investigate cause—overfeeding, dead organic matter, filter failure, cycle crash?
If 72-74°F: Float frozen water bottles, turn off lights, add fans, perform 25% water change with cooler water (64-66°F)

If Above 74°F: CRITICAL—perform 50% water change with water at 60-65°F (carefully—max 3°F drop per hour), float multiple frozen bottles, increase surface agitation, add ice packs to filter intake (sealed bags only), move tank to cooler location
Monitor: Test temperature every 30 minutes, aim for 68°F, then stabilize at 64-66°F
Ongoing: Arrange permanent cooling (chiller, AC) before next heat event

content.text: During heat emergencies, dissolved oxygen plummets. Add airstone for increased surface agitation. Axolotl gasping at surface = oxygen deprivation emergency.
Filter maintenance impacts water quality. Improper cleaning kills beneficial bacteria.

content.text: Filter Cleaning Best Practices

items: Never Clean All Media at Once: Stagger cleaning—clean mechanical media one week, biological media next month
Save Old Filter Media: When replacing worn media, run old and new together for 2-3 weeks—bacteria colonize new media
Don't Over-Clean: Filter media should look dirty (brownish)—that's bacteria colonies, not filth
Clean During Water Changes: Use bucket of removed tank water for rinsing media—convenient and safe

content.text: Short Absence (3-7 Days)

items: Adults: Can safely skip feeding 1 week—perform water change before leaving
Juveniles: Arrange pet sitter or use automatic feeder (risky—can overfeed)
Temperature: Ensure cooling equipment reliable—consider backup fans if using AC
Test Parameters: Before leaving, ensure ammonia/nitrites 0 ppm
Water Level: Top off water to account for evaporation (especially if using fans)

content.text: Extended Absence (1-4 Weeks)

items: Pet Sitter REQUIRED: Water changes cannot be skipped beyond 10-14 days
Written Instructions: Leave detailed care sheet with exact portions, water change steps, emergency contacts
Pre-Portioned Food: Prepare individual servings in dated containers—prevents overfeeding
Test Kit: Leave test kit, show sitter how to use—check parameters if axolotl seems lethargic
Backup Plan: Arrange backup sitter in case primary unavailable—have exotic vet contact ready

content.text: Tracking water parameters over time helps identify trends and prevent crises.
What to Record

items: Date and time of test
Ammonia (ppm)
Nitrites (ppm)
Nitrates (ppm)
pH
Temperature (°F)
Water change performed (yes/no, % changed)
Feeding amount and type
Observations (axolotl behavior, appetite, appearance)

content.text: Record-Keeping Methods

items: Notebook: Simple, low-tech, can sketch observations
Spreadsheet: Excel/Google Sheets—easy to graph trends over time
Aquarium Apps: Aquarium Note, AquariumDrunk—built-in parameter tracking and alerts
Photos: Take weekly photos of test results—visual record of parameter trends

content.text: Tracking trends is MORE valuable than individual tests. If nitrates rise from 10 ppm → 15 ppm → 25 ppm over 3 weeks, you need more frequent water changes BEFORE they reach dangerous levels.
